HG=F

Copper Futures (HG=F) Conviction Level: Bearish

Trade Execution Plan (1-5 Day Horizon)

  • Action: Avoid Long Positions
  • Entry Price: N/A (Initiating new long positions is not advised due to the clear bearish signal.)
  • Stop Loss: N/A ()

Exchange: COMEX (CME Group) | Currency: USD | Contract Size: 25,000 Pounds

High-Grade Copper Futures, tracked by the continuous contract ticker HG=F, are standardized legal agreements to buy or sell 25,000 pounds of copper at a predetermined price on a future delivery date. Traded on the COMEX, they are the primary global benchmark for the price of copper and are used extensively by producers, industrial consumers, and financial institutions.

The core purpose of copper futures is for commercial price risk management (hedging) and speculation. A construction company might buy futures to lock in the cost of copper piping for a future project, while a mining firm might sell futures to guarantee a price for its production. Speculators provide liquidity by absorbing this risk in the hopes of profiting from price changes.

A futures contract is a form of derivative and does not represent ownership of physical metal in a vault. It is an obligation to transact in the future. While physical delivery can occur, the vast majority of contracts are settled financially (closed out) before expiration. The price of HG=F reflects the market's real-time, collective forecast for the value of copper at a future point in time.
